references.text: Waypoints Vol 05: PPL/CPL Air Law. Chapter 1: Administration and Operations

questions.question: 'CAA' stands for ____________________. It is a (private/government) organisation.
What is the main role of the CAA?
questions.answer: Set policy and standards and promulgate rules and procedures for the safe and efficient operation of aircraft.

questions.question: What is the main task of Airways New Zealand?
questions.answer: Provide Air Traffic Services required by aircraft.

questions.question: What is the main role of MetService with regard to aviation?
What is the main role of Aspeq (formerly Aviation Services Limited ASL))?
questions.answer: Administer licensing functions, eg. theory and flight exams.

questions.question: What does ICAO stand for?
What is the role of ICAO, and how does it relate to New Zealand aviation?
questions.answer: Set standards and practices for international aviation. Many NZ rules and standards are based on ICAO documents.

questions.question: What are the three main areas of interest to pilots in the Civil Aviation Act (1990)?
questions.answer: The requirement to register aircraft (Section 6). The requirement for participants in NZ aviation to hold an 'aviation document (eg. license, permit, etc.) (Section 7). The requirement for participants in NZ aviation to ensure compliance, eg. management systems, training plans, etc. (Section 12).

questions.question: When considering a person for an aviation document, the _______________ test considers, among other things, a person's history, experience, mental health, and transport safety offence convictions.

references.text: Criteria for fit and proper person test (Civil Aviation Act)

questions.question: The Director of the CAA may require __________ or __________ of persons and/or organisations who whole aviation documents, and those documents may be either __________ or __________ if deemed to be in the interests of safety.

references.text: Safety and security inspections and monitoring (Civil Aviation Act, Section 15)
Power to suspend aviation document or impose conditions (Civil Aviation Act, Section 17/18)

questions.question: The Authority may delegate functions to (CAA employees/both CAA employees and non-CAA employees).
questions.answer: Both CAA employees and non-CAA employees.

references.text: Delegation of Director's functions of powers (Civil Aviation Act, Section 23A)

questions.question: What does CAR stand for?
Which organisation produces the CARs?
What are the two types of CA rules?
CA Rules are divided into _____, each dealing with a particular aspect of aviation.
Give the names of the following CAR Parts: Part 12; Part 39; Part 43; Part 47; Part 61; Part 67; Part 91; Part 92; Part 115; Part 119; Part 121; Part 125; Part 135; Part 137.
questions.answer: Part 12: Accident, incident and statistics. Part 39: Airworthiness directives. Part 43: General maintenance rules. Part 47: Aircraft registration and markings. Part 61: Pilot licenses and ratings. Part 67: Medical standards and certification. Part 91: General operating and flight rules. Part 92: Carriage of dangerous goods. Part 119: Air operator - certification. Part 121: Air operations - large aeroplanes. Part 125: Air operations - medium aeroplanes. Part 135: Air operations - helicopters and small aeroplanes. Part 137: Agricultural aircraft operations.

questions.question: Who issues Advisory Circulars (ACs), and where can you find them?
questions.answer: The CAA. Through the CAA website: www.caa.govt.nz.

questions.question: What does AIP stand for? Who is responsible for its contents? Who publishes it?
questions.answer: Aeronautical Information Publication. The CAA. Airways New Zealand.

questions.question: AIPNZ Volume 1 contains GEN (__________ information), ENR (__________ information), and AD (__________ information).
AIPNZ Volume 2 and 3 contain GEN, ENR, and AD information, procedures and charts specific to _____ flight.
AIPNZ Volume 4 contains GEN, ENR, and AD information, procedures and charts specific to _____ flight.

The AIP __________ (referred to as SUP) contains __________ and __________ to the AIPNZ documents, as well as information and procedures of a (temporary/permanent) nature not urgent enough to warrant issue by ________, or information too extensive to be issued by ________.
questions.answer: Supplement. Additions. Amendments. Temporary. NOTAM. NOTAM.

questions.question: The AIRAC (__________ __________ __________ and __________) cycle has _____ effective dates, which are _____ days apart.

references.text: AIRAC Cycle Dates (AIRAC cycle dates at bottom of page)

questions.question: AIP Volumes 1-4 are amended _____ times annually. The AIP Supplement is amended _____ times annually. The amendment dates follow the ________ cycle.
What information does a NOTAM contain?
questions.answer: Temporary changes to operationally significant information that needs to be promulgated immediately.

questions.question: NOTAM are available via the internet on the _____ website, as part of __________ briefings, or from _____ units during flight.
What is the difference between a Series A and Series B NOTAM?
questions.answer: Series A: primarily domestic information. Series B: primarily international information.

questions.question: Decode this NOTAM identifier: A0906/18B02.
questions.answer: Series type A NOTAM (domestic), serial number 0906, issued 2018, part 2 (B) of 2 (02).

questions.question: In a NOTAM identifier, what do the letters N, R, and C stand for? For example: A0006/16 NOTAMR A0906/16.
questions.answer: N = New, R = Replacement, C = Cancellation.
